title: Can humans digest cellulose? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well perhaps we already can, it’s just that we aren’t designed to be especially good at it! Since the human genome doesn’t encode a cellulase like EC 3.2.1.4, we depend on microbes to digest cellulose for us. However our gut transit time is only about 6 or 7 hours and this doesn’t give enough time for our gut bacteria to do very much of this degradation. Herbivores tend to have very long intestines indeed for this very reason – the gut transit time is around 48 hours in horses, for example. Now it probably would be possible for a human intestine and its microbes to adjust to a cellulose-rich diet if we go the way of the panda. Panda genomes don’t encode cellulase so they depend on microbes; they also have a short intestine like ours with a similar transit time. So how do they manage? Well, they have to eat a huge mass of leaves in comparison to their bodyweight, which they digest rather inefficiently (panda poo tends to have a lot of identifiable, semi-digested leaves and stalks in it), and they also restrict their calorie-burning activity. So you might like to try the experiment – increase your leafy intake by several orders of magnitude and just lie on the sofa all day watching TV (except for many breaks to poo – though try not to be too far from the bathroom so that you don’t have to use up too much energy). Do humans already have cellulose-degrading bacteria? The answer is yes. Although this paper (Chassard et al., 2010) found that individuals with a lot of cellulolytic microbes also had a correspondingly high population of methanogens. Does this mean that we’d expect vegans to fart a lot? I don’t know, but maybe that’s the follow up study: The cellulose‐degrading microbial community of the human gut varies according to the presence or absence of methanogens

Our bodies are unable to breakdown cellulose. This is because of the structure it has. Interestingly enough, cellulose is very similar to starch, which we can break down. It is made of repeating glucose units bonded together. The deference lies in their orientation. While starch has glucose molecules that are all oriented in the same direction, glucose alternates between one glucose “facing up” and one glucose “facing down”. This small difference makes glucose impossible for the enzymes in the body to successfully break it down and so it just goes right through indigested. Crazy isn’t it? You can have two things that have the exact same chemical composition, the same mass, and yet you change the orientation of one of the molecules in it and suddenly your body has no clue what to do with it. Cellulose is one of the components that makes up “fiber” in your meals and it helps you poop. So while you may not be able to digest it, cellulose can still help your body function well.

When trying to find out about human bioavailability of cellulose, most literature sway the subject by the fact we don't produce cellulase. But as do ruminants !How come studies trying to observe effects of dietary fiber, note elevation of small fatty acids alias SCFAs. Those fatty acids are down-products of cellulose digestion by colon microbiota, which are partly taken through the colon wall and used as markers of colonic population and also a source of energy (~10% of the total energy consumption). http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3735932/ It may depend of everyone microflora, as it changes from one individual to another. Mostly people producing methane have the best ability to degrade cellulose. The cellulolytic microflora of the human colon: evidence of microcrystalline cellulose-degrading bacteria in methane-excreting subjects But when talking about cellulose, we often think about grass or hull, which are specific. By their high level of silica and lignin, it impairs cellulose digestion by micro-organisms. Whereas cellulose from succulent plants like cabbage or carrots are the more bioavailable. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1432575/pdf/gut00393-0005.pdf

The idea that cellulose absolutely do not digest in humans have been debunked in the last 30 years. But most biology text books have not caught up with this, so most people generally understand that humans do not digest dietary fibers. Humans also possess bacteria in the colon to digest all kinds of dietary fiber. The details are given under the Fiber and Fermentation section of Dietary fiber - Wikipedia. This was a bit of surprise to me, but very interesting read as to colon as an important producer of nutrients.

Humans are unable to digest cellulose because the appropriate enzymes to breakdown the beta acetal linkages are lacking. Indigestible cellulose is the fiber which aids in the smooth working of the intestinal tract. unlike cows for ex. don't have the necessary bacteria in their intestines that make the enzymes necessary to breakdown the 1-4 beta glucose bonds. So we cannot break down cellulose into its constituent glucose molecules as we do with starch.

No,humans cannot digest cellulose since the enzymes cellulase lacks in human digestive system. But however this cellulase is secreted by few intestinal bacteria of rodents and cow etc and wood fungi which breaks down cellulose to glucose and used as metabolic fuel.
Humans cannot as we lack the enzyme cellulase to break down cellulose.  Thus, it does not get digested in our gut, and passes through our behind the next time we do "The Number Two".
